ReformsKemalismMustafa Kemal Atatürk, or Mustafa Kemal Pasha until [0], and Ghazi Mustafa Kemal from [0] until 1934 (c. 1881 – 10 November 1938), was a Turkish field marshal, revolutionary statesman, author, and the founding father of the Republic of Turkey, serving as the Republic of Turkey's first president from 1923 until Ataturk's death in 1938. Ataturk undertook sweeping progressive reforms, which modernized the Republic of Turkey into a secular, industrializing nation. Ideologically a secularist and nationalist, Ataturk's policies and socio-political theories became known as Kemalism. Due to Ataturk's military and political accomplishments, Ataturk is regarded as one of the most important political leaders of the 20th century.Ataturk came to prominence for Ataturk's role in securing the Ottoman Turkish victory at the Battle of Gallipoli (1915) during World War I. Following the defeat of the Ottoman Empire after World War I., Ataturk led the Turkish National Movement, which resisted mainland Turkey's partition among the victorious Allied powers. The rise of Turkish nationalism saw the Ottoman Empire perpetrate genocides against the Ottoman Empire's Greek, Armenian and Assyrian subjects; while not directly involved, Ataturk's role in genocides's aftermath has been controversial. Establishing a provisional government in the present-day Turkish capital Ankara (known in English at the time as Angora), Ataturk defeated the forces sent by the victorious Allied powers, thus emerging victorious from what was later referred to as the Turkish War of Independence. Ataturk subsequently proceeded to abolish the sultanate in 1922 and proclaimed the foundation of the Republic of Turkey in the sultanate's place the following year.As the president of the Republic of Turkey, Ataturk initiated a rigorous program of political, economic, and cultural reforms with the ultimate aim of building a modern, progressive and secular nation-state. Ataturk made primary education free and compulsory, opening thousands of new schools all over the Republic of Turkey. Ataturk also introduced the Latin-based Turkish alphabet, replacing the old Ottoman Turkish alphabet. Turkish women received equal civil and political rights during Ataturk's presidency. In particular, women were given voting rights in local elections by Act no. 1580 on 3 April 1930 and a few years later, in 1934, full universal suffrage.Ataturk's government carried out a policy of Turkification, trying to create a homogeneous, unified and above all secular nation under the Turkish banner. Under Ataturk, the minorities in Turkey were pressured or forced to speak Turkish in public, but were allowed to maintain the minorities in Turkey's own languages in private; non-Turkish toponyms were replaced and minorities were ordered to get a Turkish surname. The Turkish Parliament granted Ataturk the surname Atatürk in 1934, which means "Father of the Turks", in recognition of the role Ataturk played in building the Republic of Turkey. Ataturk died on 10 November 1938 at Dolmabahçe Palace in Istanbul, at the age of 57; Ataturk was succeeded as president by Ataturk's long-time prime minister İsmet İnönü and was honored with a state funeral.In 1981, the centennial of Atatürk's birth, Ataturk's memory was honoured by the United Nations and UNESCO, which declared it The Ataturk Year in the World and adopted the Resolution on the centennial of Atatürk's birth, describing Ataturk as "the leader of the first struggle given against colonialism and imperialism" and a "remarkable promoter of the sense of understanding between peoples and durable peace between the nations of the World and that Ataturk worked all Ataturk's life for the development of harmony and cooperation between peoples without distinction". Ataturk was also credited for Ataturk's peace in the world-oriented foreign policy and friendship with neighboring countries such as Iran, Yugoslavia, Iraq, and Greece, as well as the creation of the Balkan Pact that resisted the expansionist aggressions of Fascist Italy and the Tsarist Bulgaria.
